tud.se.httpd
Class HttpServer

java.lang.Object
  java.lang.Thread
      tud.se.httpd.HttpServer
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Runnable
public class HttpServer
extends java.lang.Thread

The HttpServer maintains the server socket and accepts each connection from a client an passes it to its HttpWorker.

The server runs it its own thread. So it is possible to observe and manage it form an other thread.

Author:
suesskraut 
part of: tiny-http package: tud.se.httpd
 File: HttpServer.java

Constructor Detail

HttpServer

public HttpServer(HttpConfig c)

Constructs an HttpServer for a given HttpConfig.

The server needs to know the port on which it should listen from the config.

Parameters:
c - The config for the server.
Method Detail

setWorker

public void setWorker(HttpWorker worker)

Sets the worker to which all accepted client socket should be passed.

Parameters:
worker - The worker to set.

run

public void run()

The main server loop. This method is executed an a separat thread.

getReceivedRequests

public int getReceivedRequests()
Returns the number of already received client connetions.

Returns:
the number of already received client connetions

halt

public void halt()

This method stopps the server thread gracefully.

It must be called for restarting the server thread.

Attentation: This method may not be called from the server thread! It must be called from another thread, to guarentee that the server has been shutted down gracefully.

afterHandlingRequest

protected void afterHandlingRequest()

This hook method is called after each processed client socket.

It could be overridden to observe the server or to implement additional behavior for that server.
